@graph.name: How to Decide Between Custom Software and Off-the-Shelf Solutions
@graph.description: Step-by-step decision framework for determining whether custom software or off-the-shelf solutions are right for your business

step.name: Evaluate Your Workflow Uniqueness
step.text: Determine if your workflow is unique or provides a competitive advantage. Ask: Do you do things differently than competitors? Is your process what makes you successful?

step.name: Calculate Annual Software Costs
step.text: Add up all SaaS subscriptions, per-user costs, integration tools, and workaround time. If over $20,000/year, custom software starts making financial sense.

step.name: Assess Integration Needs
step.text: Identify how many systems need to integrate and current integration pain points. If you need 5+ integrations or have integration nightmares, custom software provides better solutions.

step.name: Project Future Growth
step.text: Determine if you're planning to scale 2x-5x in the next 2-3 years. Growth scenarios make custom software more cost-effective as SaaS pricing escalates with scale.

step.name: Calculate ROI and Break-Even
step.text: Use an ROI calculator to compare 5-year costs of custom vs off-the-shelf. Factor in development costs, maintenance, and subscription savings.

mainEntity.name: How long does custom software take to build?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most business applications take 2-6 months to build. Simple tools require 6-12 weeks, medium applications need 12-24 weeks, and complex systems take 24-52+ weeks. Timeline depends on feature complexity, integrations, design requirements, and your availability for feedback. A phased approach is recommended: build core features first (8-12 weeks), launch and validate, then add enhancements.

mainEntity.name: What does custom software actually cost?

acceptedAnswer.text: Custom software costs vary by complexity: Simple applications cost $15,000-$50,000 and take 2-3 months. Medium complexity projects range from $50,000-$150,000 over 3-6 months. Complex systems cost $150,000-$500,000+ requiring 6-12+ months. Budget an additional 15-20% of development cost annually for hosting and maintenance. Custom software typically breaks even in 2-4 years when replacing existing subscriptions.

mainEntity.name: Who owns the code in custom software?

acceptedAnswer.text: You own 100% of custom software code and all related assets including source code, documentation, database schemas, and deployment instructions. There are no licensing fees or vendor lock-in. You have the license to modify, extend, or hire any developer to work on it. This is a key advantage over SaaS solutions where you own nothing.

mainEntity.name: When should I choose custom software over off-the-shelf?

acceptedAnswer.text: Choose custom software when: your workflow is unique or proprietary, you're spending $20,000+/year on software subscriptions, integration of 5+ systems is critical, you need a competitive advantage, long-term ownership matters, compliance requires custom solutions (HIPAA, SOC2), or you're planning significant growth. If standard processes work fine and budget is limited, stick with off-the-shelf solutions.

mainEntity.name: What is the ROI of custom business software?

acceptedAnswer.text: Custom software typically delivers ROI through: elimination of subscription costs (average $20,000-$50,000/year saved), reduced workaround time (25-40% productivity increase), decreased error rates, and increased capacity without adding staff. Most businesses see break-even in 2-4 years with typical ROI of 150-400% over 5 years. After year 3-4, custom becomes significantly cheaper than SaaS while you own a valuable business asset.

mainEntity.name: Can custom software integrate with existing systems?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, if the system has an API or accessible database, custom software can integrate. Common integrations include CRMs (Salesforce, HubSpot), accounting software (QuickBooks, Xero), e-commerce platforms (Shopify, WooCommerce), payment processors (Stripe, PayPal), email platforms (Mailchimp, SendGrid), and Google Workspace/Microsoft 365. Integration capabilities are a major advantage of custom software over limited off-the-shelf integrations.

mainEntity.name: What ongoing costs should I expect with custom software?

acceptedAnswer.text: Ongoing costs for custom software include: hosting ($50-$500/month depending on scale), maintenance ($200-$2,000/month for updates and support), SSL certificates and domains ($100-$500/year), and third-party service fees (email, SMS, payment processing). Budget 15-20% of development cost annually. For example, a $75,000 project requires $11,000-$15,000/year in ongoing costs. This is typically much less than escalating SaaS subscriptions.

mainEntity.name: How do I choose the right custom software developer?

acceptedAnswer.text: Choose developers based on: business understanding (not just technical skills), relevant experience in your industry, clear development process and communication style, post-launch support options, and cultural fit. Ask to see 3 similar completed projects, speak with past clients, understand their testing and security processes, and confirm you'll own all code. Avoid developers who guarantee fixed prices without requirements, say yes to everything, have no portfolio, or won't discuss maintenance.
